I am not sure how I got sucked into 55 hours of this game at the time of writing this review.  I was concerned with the low-poly graphics not being immersive, but I was wrong.  Less is more.  I think my imagination fills in the rest and really makes it engaging, plus a fun base building system (build anywhere), and fun weapons to go find in interesting places held by scary bosses.  This is one of the few games to give me jump scare when a sneaky zombo pops around a corner after waiting for you there.  Unscripted fun at it's best.  Worth every penny at full price.

The storage situations a little different for me. It has rare items you can find or buy, and harder areas to go to once you are a little more together. And you can customize most aspects of the game play to suit your play style. I do recommend this.

Once you get to later game or even early game for that matter its not too difficult, all challenges or zombie/ zombie bosses can basically be easily killed by standing ontop of almost anything, in most cases a car thats sitting around. The zombie ai isnt advanced enough yet to be able to climb or really do anything about it. The points of interest are well made and look amazing but back to the zombie bosses and zombies themselves theres not enough variety. The zombie bosses are all basically the same with no real distinguishing factors between each other. Just bigger version of a regular zombie with a lot more hp. But its a good time killer overall and if multiplayer gets added i can see it being pretty fun. It has great potential.

This is a really fun zombie/survival game at a great price. At the time of this review, I have approx. 105 hours of early access game play, and feel like I have gotten great value for the money I spent so far. The game also appears to get substantial and relatively frequent updates.

While the game map doesn't seem particularly large at first glance, the open world is surprisingly large, with lots of interesting points of interest to discover and explore. You can play in a third person or first person view. There are also lots of great weapons to find and play with, that sound and feel real (to me at least).  I also really like the art style.

The fact that the world resets everytime you reload the game isn't something I am a fan of though (although you do keep everything you have claimed/built/placed once you save). The sound system still needs some work - sometimes it seems like there is no sound, but when a strong storm happens it is too loud (I usually mute until the storm subsides). The game also still needs the addition of explainations for how various things work - luckily the internet is very helpful until this gets added.

If an open world zombie survival game sounds like something you would like, you should definitely check Surroundead out.

This is as of 24/11/2025, quite early in the road map.

Fist off, thank you to the developers for such a treat of a game. I found it hard to put down once I picked it up! I overall enjoyed my time, and had an extremely smooth experience with 0 crashes or issues, and found no bugs.

Exploration is really fun and engaging with the random potential elements that occur, this allowed me to revisist previous locations but have a different experience.

The graphical style although not everyones cup of tea for certain, is clean, easy to navigate and stands out! I sincerly look forward to the introduction of more!

Combat although straight forward, wasn't dull at all. It created in many situations a sense of excitement and rush! Some unique environments altered the way I went about combat, and I enjoyed the fact there were different approachs I could take to handle the situation the way I wanted to, and wasn't locked into any one way!

The variety of weapons was awesome to discover and expand into over the course of the game, as well as vehicle variety, althought RNG had it's way with hiding all the vehicle repair kits until the end of my run!

I found a lack of purpose overall after about 10 hours of exploring. There is no direction in the current state that pushes a player in any direction clearly. I decided to chase the achievements as a sort of 'task list' to give myself direction and this worked out pleasantly.

The Infestations were cool engagement, and I enjoyed the changes they brought to the POI. Although after defeating the first one, and the second and third, I realised there was no objective or point in doing so. I have faith this will change in later versions. The bones are there, and they are strong!

The game had a similar feel to State of Decay in my opinion, without the community side (yet).

I didn't get to much into the building side of things, I put down the 3 crafting tables and came to the conclusion that I had already found, or could buy better so moved on rather quickly down those avenues.

I understand that the road map covers a lot of things that I find will expand the game dramatically and create an excellent experience for all that play! However the above review is in it's current state.

In later version, I will be running on more scarce/rare loot on the extreme side, to give the games later stages, a feeling of awe, and strategy relating to use of firearms and throwables. As I found I was swimming in weapons after 4 hours of play, after 10 I had a a kit of named weapons.

I look forward to updates! And can't wait to see what's coming next! Best of luck to all the survivors to come, and those already out there!

I would like to personally see a few additions to the game in the future:
(I know it's been talked about before) Online Coop would be delightful! Playing with friends on PermaDeath would be dope.
Changing of seasons depending on where on the map you are. 
Decor for houses - holiday packs (Sell these for $5 a pack as DLC)
Pets - Adopting a dog or cat to roam around your base
Gardening - Being able to plant food (Tomato, Potato, Corn, etc) leading to additional cooking options (Full Meals with Buffs maybe)
Roaming Hordes of Zombies (The longer you survive the bigger the horde)
Zombies that specially target your base (Similar to 7 Days to Die)
Randomization on character customization

Guarantee the developer has heard all these ideas at some point but I very much look forward to the future of this game!

I will say though, the only downside currently is that there isn't a lot of content in the game itself. Once you explore the map, kill all the bosses, and build your base, there really isn't anything left to do. Based on the road map though, this will be fixed later down the line since there are plans for quests, a bounty system, and then stuff in regard to settlements. There is also no co-op currently, but this is also a planned feature down the line in the road map, so I guess we'll have to wait.

Overall, while you may not be able to sink hundreds of hours into this game yet, it was and still is quite enjoyable with the number of hours I've currently put into this game.

Here is a list of the things i currently like and dislike:

Positives:
- You can basically tweak every world setting in your game, from weapons getting damaged, the amount of hunger/thirst you lose, attachments durability, everything you can tweak the way you like.

- The game looks really good, the lighting makes the game look so much better than it actually does!

- It runs so well, as it should since it's a low poly game. I've got a 3070 with a 5700x3D and i'm running all on cinematic @1080 getting 200fps +

- Combat feels nice, the meele weapons swing feel impactful and effective. There are a big variety of guns and the gun play is pretty good aswell!

- The map is pretty big and full, i never found a place in the map where there's basically nothing.

- It feels very casual, usually these kinds of games are very hardcore and hard to get into, but this one i felt more relaxed playing, there are a lot of mechanics, don't get me wrong, but they are straight foward and easy to get into.

- Lot's of NPCs around the map, sadly you can't interact with them, but they make the game feel more alive.

- The big POI's feel very different from one another.

Negatives:

- The inventory is a bit of a grey line for me... From one side is nice, because i'm a bit of a loot goblin, and i can basically get everything that i see in front of me with the endless stacking backpacks. But from the other side, it's quite annoying to open a crap ton of backpacks everytime i open a new container to loot just to get to a open spot. This gets progressively worse the farther you get into the game.

- The gameplay loop, as you would expect with these kinds of games in single player, gets a bit boring, i'm already fully kitted out with legendary weapons and there's no incentive to keep playing.

- The vehicles all sound the same, i wasn't expecting every car to sound different, but it feels quite weird to have a Golf Cart and a Military Humvee to have the same sound.

- The AI needs some serious work, the game gets very trivial as soon as you can either shoot all the zombies from outside their aggro range, or by just climbing a car.

- While the big POI's are very diverse and different, the smaller ones look exactly the same. Gas Stations being the biggest offenders here..

- The traders don't have nearly enough money, everytime i've raided a big POI, i've had to keep exiting to the menu and logging in again to reset the NPCs inventory, to then buying more backpacks or ammo, to finally they be able to afford what i've picked up.

- I wish i could rename my saves.

- There's a waypoint guide on the top right of the minimap, which completely hides that area of the map, there's no way of minimizing that, you can zoom out completely, but then you can't see the POI's anymore.

Overall the game has a great foundation and a lot of room to improve upon, there's a couple of things wrong with the AI specially and the gameplay loop overall feels a bit repetitive, i would like a bigger incentive to play the game rather then just "survive".

Review for SurrounDead – The Underrated Survival Masterpiece

SurrounDead is one of those games that grabs you completely out of nowhere. It combines the classic feeling of true survival gaming with an open, dangerous world that keeps you constantly on edge. The atmosphere is brutally authentic — every step, every building, every item you find feels meaningful. You can tell right away that this isn’t just another loot shooter, but a game built around real survival.

The open world feels harsh, empty, yet somehow alive — exactly how a post-apocalyptic environment should be. You’re rewarded for playing carefully, looting smartly, and planning your route through abandoned areas. The progression system is addictive: every upgraded weapon, every piece of gear, every level-up makes you noticeably stronger, but never invincible.

SurrounDead achieves something many survival games fail at:
It delivers the perfect mix of tension, freedom, and challenge. Whether you're looting for hours, exploring new locations, or fighting enemies, the game stays consistently intense and immersive.

For anyone looking for an honest, atmospheric, and surprisingly deep survival open-world experience, SurrounDead is an absolute hidden gem. One of the best titles in its genre.

Surroundead doesn't offer players much to do. There's some stuff to loot, there's a couple of zeds to kill, and there's currency to accrue, but that's it. This game has a lot of potential. However, my main issue is that zombies are locked into specific poi (point of interest) locations which makes building a defensive base unnecessary. Since zombies aren't a threat in the open world, there's no constant danger. Knowing exactly where the zombies will be removes the challenge and becomes repetitive. I think Project Zomboid is a great example of wandering zombies being a constant threat, and implementing a similar system would make this game much more engaging. Zombies and loot at poi locations respawn the next morning. This makes clearing a town feel pointless, as you lose the sense of accomplishment. That being said, I bought the game on sale and don't regret the purchase. I understand it's in early access and a work in progress, but this is my current impression. I'll check back after each patch and update my review if things change. 6/10

I really want to like this game, and I kinda do, but it's just... kinda boring.
I understand it being in early access, so obviously things are gonna be a work in progress or upcoming features, but it's pretty painful in this game at times.

The gameplay loop basically boils down to explore, kill, loot, sell, repeat. This could work, but the problem here is that the loot table is pretty small, and even the unique/named items are mostly a cosmetic difference with a mild boost to stats. The zombies are all unique COSMETICALLY and that's it; there's really no difference in any engagement with the infected. All you have to do is jump on top of a car, fire off a gun to get attention, and pick them all off from the safety of 6 feet high. Even the unique zombies and the boss zombies just try to beeline their way directly towards you, and then stand idle when they can't reach you, just letting you shoot them or even just crouch-melee them. Boots-on-ground combat is definitely a challenge but it's JUST as rewarding as cheesing it.

Then there's the grid-style inventory management system. If you like to keep your stuff tidy, if you are a pack rat, if you play like a nomad, or if you're all of the above like me, then you will literally spend half of your time just doing inventory management. You have access to bags and containers for specific items, but you have to limit yourself by not putting bags inside of bags (or disable it,) or you'll end up playing tetris while thinking about that gif of spongebob pulling the bag for chocolate out of the bag for chocolate over and over and over... yanno?

Let's say you figured out the inventory management system, and you have a good start going... well, what now? The game gives ONE quest (as far as i've seen) which is "go to the main settlement." After that, it's all just exploration, which is fine. There's points of interest to explore that are fairly unique, but this game artificially inflates how dense the map actually is by dotting the entire map with tons of abandoned houses with like 2 loot chests that give mediocre stuff, and suddenly OVER HALF of the POIs become drive-through points, and half of the ones that are actually interesting are soft-locked by keycards that you can buy or loot. Good luck having the right one, though. (I spent an entire playthrough with 10+ level 0 and 1 keycards, but the only cards I ever used were 2 and 3. Maybe I'm missing something?) The card-locked places and non-abandoned ones can be fun, but then you end up just looting all of the same crap you've been looting for the last 15 hours. By the time you're done, you're either hauling an insane amount of gear to TRY to sell at a vendor (who is also just selling more of the same crap you've been looting with SOME exceptions,) only to be hit with the realization that all 4 vendors plus the wandering trader can only afford to buy a total of like 60% of your crap, which you then take that money and promptly slide it into your rectum because that's more useful than spending $2500 on 70 bullets (a high tier weapon sells for 200 at MOST)

So now you're stuck with the other 40% of the crap you couldn't sell, and some resources you want to keep, just in case they're useful. So let's set up base somewhere! Except... that's kind of pointless. Yes, you can pick a spot to call home and yes, there are quite a few buildable pieces you can craft or loot, but... other than that, the resources you've collected will more than likely end up collecting dust while you're out collecting more. There's crafting recipes for gear and other stuff... but it's all just the SAME SHIT YOU'VE BEEN LOOTING THIS WHOLE TIME (again, with a few exceptions.) There's not anything that you could craft that would give you much of an edge over the zombies (not that you'd need it,) there's only a handful of building pieces that are useful if you're building your base in a POI, and there's no real reason to stockpile anything since the traders sell what you need, it's abundant in the loot, and/or it doesn't really serve much of a purpose. There's no defense of the base, no people management, no wandering hordes, no stakes.

Let's say you looted a good amount, killed a good amount of zombies, got some money and gear, and you're confident and ready to take on the next step. Well, the next step is the same exploration loop you've been doing, but with guns and a vehicle, but the end goal is... making money you won't spend? collecting resources you won't use? collecting cool looking guns just to find out they eat more bullets than you can buy or loot, or they are worse than what you already have? Building a base that is functionally useless and aesthetically a nightmare from having to reuse tons of objects? Complete quests that... just aren't implemented yet?

I did enjoy running through the POIs and managing the radiation while fighting zombies and NPCs (which are just filler people, some vendors, and 'bad guys' to keep things interesting) but there wasn't a goal other than... seeing it, i guess. There's some story fragments you can find via readable notepads, but they blend in with the environment half of the time because they are the ONLY interactible 'item' that spawns like a normal item would. Everything else is in a chest. No guns or ammo on tabletops, no decorations. The stack of papers acting as the fragment, and that's it.

Don't get me wrong, this game has SO MUCH POTENTIAL!! It's like a healthy blend of 7 days to die, project zomboid, dayz, and probably other games i'm not thinking of or haven't played, and it's definitely in my wheelhouse... but the problem is that the only thing this game offers are unfinished similarities to the unique aspects of those games - zomboid's exploration and melee combat, dayz's grid inventory, 7 days' focus on guns, etc.. I'm loving the melting pot of vibes this game has for those titans of the genre, but it needs more work. I'm just afraid of this game falling into the early access hell.

Lastly, I know this game was made by one person, and I give them all of the props in the world for the effort they have made, so I'll still have my eye on this game for a while, but right now it feels like one of those old xbox 360 games that were an imitation of another popular title but without the comittment to make one thing really good and instead opting for a tiny bit of everything.

I know my words can be a bit abrasive but I do like the game's potential, but i'm having a hard time putting any significant time into it because it feels like i've hit the endgame after 20 hours. If there's more quests, better building, or better/more unique gear implemented, then I'll be able to sink more hours into it.

Surroundead is close to having something special, but right now the experience feels empty and unbalanced. I have played around six hours and the difficulty curve collapses as soon as you find a decent ranged weapon. Zombies only react within a very small radius, so simply stepping back a short distance allows you to pick off entire groups without risk. Add a suppressor and you are practically untouchable.

The world itself feels abandoned in the wrong way. Instead of a chaotic apocalypse, most of the map is calm and uneventful. Zombies only gather in specific points of interest and there are too few to create any real tension. Of the limited enemy types, only the sprinters add excitement and force you to change how you play. The game needs more variety and at least one ranged threat to keep players on edge.

Bandits appear in the world and they do shoot, but they are extremely rare. In my entire time playing I only encountered four. On the other hand, zombie AI is the bigger issue. If you climb on top of almost anything, they simply gather at the base and stare. Cars, low roofs, boxes, any elevation at all keeps you perfectly safe. That means base building away from major locations becomes a peaceful creative mode where nothing attacks you or even notices you exist.

The description promises an apocalyptic catastrophe, but the current experience feels far too safe. It is more like wandering through a huge open landscape with a few isolated pockets of danger that are easily avoided if you want to.

This is early access, so there is room and time for improvement. With stronger AI, more threatening encounters, and a world that feels alive and dangerous at all times, Surroundead could become a compelling survival title. As it stands today, it needs more development before I can recommend it.

Getting this game on sale provides a decent amount of value. SurrounDead is not a bad game, nor does it feel like bloatware or abandonware. But it does feel dead, and you can tell that the game is made by a solo-developer. There are many small issues that may add up, turning potential players away from this title to other, more polished zombie survival games (and there are *a lot* of those!). 

The two most glaring issues as of right now include the world feeling empty, and combat being dreadfully easy. Zombies are mostly limited to preset spawn points and you can walk from one POI to another without any worry of being in danger. There is little decor save for grass, rocks and trees to keep your senses stimulated as you trudge through the world that looks nice mostly because it's developed with UE5. When you do come across a zombie, the combat is painfully easy. Even ignoring the well-known fact that you can stand on top of a car, surrounded by literally *every single* enemy on the map, killing them all from the safety of your perch—taking a "realistic" approach to combat is just as easy. The player can swing a melee weapon faster than enemies can attack; fast enough to repeatedly stagger enemies, preventing them from hitting you in the 2-4 hits it takes to kill them. With the right weapons, like a common baseball bat likely to be found in the first few minutes of gameplay, it is even possible to take on groups of zombies less than 30 minutes into your save. This was my experience, looting the mall POI when suddenly I was swarmed by about 10 zombies. That should have been it— I should have died, but instead spamming left-click without any strategy let me take them all on with about 20% health remaining, and *no* status effects applied *whatsoever*. It feels like different medical items exist solely to have items that are "harder" to craft and therefore heal marginally more HP. The settings do offer gameplay customization sliders, but making combat more challenging shouldn't lean on the tired trope of bullet-sponges. As a small aside, the game gets *DARK* at night. You will need to increase the gamma to at least 2 (out of a maximum value of 3) if you value seeing anything but a monitor that looks like it could be off. 

Positive aspects include the game's looting system, loot is distributed in a manner that is neither scarce nor overly-abundant, with a decent amount of variability in weapon types, rarity, and cosmetic items. However, weapon rarity needs balancing as (so far) higher-tier weapons only offer small differences to their common counterparts. Health, energy, hunger, thirst and energy meters are a feature that offers the potential for more immersive, life-simulator-y character management, but so far feels shallow. Just as there is a skill point that allows for passive health regen, there should also be status effects or scenarios where health naturally degrades. Items restore an unsatisfying amount of hunger compared to how quickly the meter degrades — but the basics are there. The vehicle system is satisfactory, if a bit simplistic. Like many of the game's core mechanics and aspects, it feels like a State of Decay inspired title that was dunked into a vat of DayZ— only without any community or world-building features. 

Given that the developer is still active (though as of writing this review is currently grinding out hours in Battlefield 6) I have hopes that updates will continue to flow, and eventually a more clear vision will start to emerge from the overly-ambitious roadmap. Given the game has been in Early Access since 2022, and hasn't even breached the First phase of the roadmap, it's clear that this is a passion project that the developer will have to actively fight with, such that it does not eventually become abandonware.

At least at this point in Early Access, I'm going to say I'm not really into SurrounDead. I've played Project Zomboid, 7 Days to Die, and plenty of other great survival games like NeoScavenger. For me, the game play is too arcade-like for a post-apocalyptic survival game.

Maybe arcade combat and boss killing loot mechanics are a plus to others, but I wouldn't suggest this game to any of my friends. I had a few hours of fun so I don't regret my purchase, but I found the combat and survival aspects a bit too shallow.

Note: This review focuses on the current state in Early Access. I will change my review in the future if updates warrant it.
